ANSWER: Based on the diagnosis of gastroenteritis with dehydration, I recommend a comprehensive treatment approach that combines evidence-based medical management with patient-centered care strategies. The treatment plan includes prompt rehydration using oral rehydration solutions as first-line therapy, supplemented by antiemetic medication such as ondansetron if nausea impairs fluid intake. Patients should be advised to sip small amounts frequently, rest, and gradually resume a bland diet. Monitoring hydration status, symptom progression, and electrolyte balance is essential, with follow-up within 24-48 hours to ensure improvement. In cases of persistent vomiting, inability to maintain oral intake, or worsening symptoms, IV fluids and further medical evaluation are necessary. Clear patient education on dehydration signs, medication use, and when to seek urgent care will support adherence. Additional referrals to gastroenterology may be needed if symptoms persist or worsen. This strategy aims to restore optimal hydration, minimize complications, and facilitate recovery while considering the patient's communication style and ensuring appropriate support and follow-up.
